smackfu,"2012-12-26T15:23:46.647Z","Pretty standard for a micro-scale Architecture set","

This is a pretty standard Architecture set: lots of small pieces, all in the same color, and lots of repetition in the build.
column2:
I'm not a huge fan of that, but it does seem like a requirement when you are depicting real buildings with lots of symmetry and multiple floors.

The build has some interesting techniques to it.
column3: The whole structure is shifted a half brick from the base. &nbsp
column4: The roof tiles are 2x1 pieces centered on a brick with a holed stud, which is a bit unusual for an official build but it holds well enough. &nbsp
column5: I was surprised it wasn't pointed out in the instructions. &nbsp
column6: There's one other dodgy bit with a vertical 2x1 flat tile attached vertically that really seems to intrude on a nearby stud. &nbsp
column7:
It's not structural though so it doesn't really matter in the grand scheme of things.

My main problem with this set is that it doesn't really look like the real Big Ben.
column8: The color is pretty spot-on, and the lower tower and parliament buildings are as good as they could be at this scale, but the top of the tower is just wrong. &nbsp
column9: The real one has big square clockfaces that don't stick out and cover the entire side of the top, while Lego decided to use smaller round stock clock pieces that have to stick out an extra piece's thickness to attach. &nbsp
column10: A custom 2x2 printed brick with the real Big Ben clock face would have made this set look so much better. &nbsp
column11:
If they can print up the Big Ben name plate brick, they should also print up other pieces that are much more important to the build.

This is a general issue with these micro-scale Architecture sets.
column12: They choose scales that are just too small to accurately reflect a real building's nuance and details. &nbsp

,TRUE,5,4,4,3,5 Dude45","2016-09-18T15:45:43.753Z","Could have resembled Big Ben much more","

There are two LEGO renditions of Big Ben, the iconic London building. One is a giant model (10253) and the other one is this microscaled Architecture set.
Usually I think Architecture sets do a great job of portraying their originals at microscale, but this one is unfortunately an exception. The problem is the tower'
column2: s clockwork. It goes 2 studs out from the tower when it&#39
column3: s supposed to be at the same level. While you probably will recognize Big Ben, the model could have resembled it much more.&nbsp

column1: You can alleviate the problem to some degree by removing the 2x2 plates that for no good reason has been used underneath the clock pieces, but it'
column2: s still not satisfactory. Using a centered 1x1 brick inside with 4 knobs would probably have been a better choice.

column1: The standard LEGO 2x2 clock looks odd in this context. A specially made Big Ben clock brick would be required here, which is not much to ask for given the very high price level for Architecture sets.
One thing this model does better than 10253: the dark green color chosen for the greenery outside the building. (10253 uses a lighter green color which does not look good.)
